defs.docs: Library for subdividing shapes made of triangles.

attributes.value: / Library for subdividing shapes made of triangles.
/ This library defines `Subdivided<T, S>`. This struct
/ allows one to define a base shape using `S` and the
/ `BaseShape` trait, and to subdivide it using the
/ interpolation functions defined as part of `S`.
/ This includes a few base shapes:
/ - Icosahedron
/ - Tetrahedron
/ - Square
/ - Triangle
/ - Cube
/ ## Example usage
/ ```rust
/ use hexasphere::shapes::IcoSphere;
/ fn main() {
/     // Create a new sphere with 20 subdivisions
/     // an no data associated with the vertices.
/     let sphere = IcoSphere::new(20, |_| ());
/     let points = sphere.raw_points();
/     for p in points {
/         println!("{:?} is a point on the sphere!", p);
/     let indices = sphere.get_all_indices();
/     for triangle in indices.chunks(3) {
/         println!(
/             "[{}, {}, {}] is a triangle on the resulting shape",
/             triangle[0],
/             triangle[1],
/             triangle[2],
/ # Features
/ - `adjacency` allows the user to create neighbour maps from
/ the indices provided by the `Subdivided` struct.

defs.name: geometric_slerp
defs.value: pub fn geometric_slerp(Vec3A, Vec3A, f32) -> Vec3A
defs.docs:
Implements spherical interpolation along the great arc created by
 the initial points. This returns a new point `p` percent of the way
 along that arc.

attributes.value: / Implements spherical interpolation along the great arc created by
/ the initial points. This returns a new point `p` percent of the way
/ along that arc.
/ Note: `a` and `b` should both be normalized for normalized results.

defs.name: geometric_slerp_half
defs.docs:
This is an optimization for the `geometric_slerp` in the case where `p`
 is `0.5` or 50%.

attributes.value: / This is an optimization for the `geometric_slerp` in the case where `p`
/ Note: `a` and `b` should both be normalized for normalized results.

defs.name: geometric_slerp_multiple
defs.docs:
This is an optimization for the case where multiple points require the
 calculation of varying values of `p` for the same start and end points.

attributes.value: / This is an optimization for the case where multiple points require the
/ calculation of varying values of `p` for the same start and end points.
/ See the intended use in [`BaseShape::interpolate_multiple`](crate::BaseShape::interpolate_multiple).
/ Note: `a` and `b` should both be normalized for normalized results.

defs.name: normalized_lerp
defs.value: pub fn normalized_lerp(Vec3A, Vec3A, f32) -> Vec3A
defs.docs:
Performs normalized linear interpolation. This creates distortion when
 compared with spherical interpolation along an arc, however this is most
 likely faster, as though this avoids expensive sin and acos calculations.

attributes.value: / Performs normalized linear interpolation. This creates distortion when
/ compared with spherical interpolation along an arc, however this is most
/ likely faster, as though this avoids expensive sin and acos calculations.

defs.name: normalized_lerp_half
defs.docs: This is an optimization of `normalized_lerp` which avoids a multiplication.

attributes.value: / This is an optimization of `normalized_lerp` which avoids a multiplication.

defs.name: normalized_lerp_multiple
defs.docs:
This is provided as a plug in for people who need it, but this implements
 essentially the same algorithm as `BaseShape` would without ever being
 reimplemented.

attributes.value: / This is provided as a plug in for people who need it, but this implements
/ essentially the same algorithm as `BaseShape` would without ever being
/ reimplemented.

defs.docs: Simple linear interpolation. No weirdness here.

defs.docs: Gives the average of the two points.

This is provided as a plug in for people who need it, but this implements

defs.name: IcoSphereBase
defs.docs: Implements an icosahedron as the base shape.

attributes.value: / Implements an icosahedron as the base shape.
/ - 12 vertices
/ - 20 faces
/ - 30 edges
/ This shape has the best results for a sphere.
/ The resulting smaller triangles are close to being
/ equilateral, so if one draws lines from the center
/ of the each triangle to the middle of the each edge
/ then the result will be 12 pentagons and many hexagons.

defs.name: IcoSphere
defs.docs: Icosphere.

attributes.value: / Icosphere.
/ See [`IcoSphereBase`].

defs.name: radius_shapes
defs.docs:
Calculate distance from the center of a shape (pentagon or hexagon)
 to one of the vertices of the shape.

attributes.value: / Calculate distance from the center of a shape (pentagon or hexagon)
/ to one of the vertices of the shape.
/ In other words, the radius of the circumscribed circle.

defs.name: TetraSphereBase
defs.docs: Implements a tetrahedron as the base shape.

attributes.value: / Implements a tetrahedron as the base shape.
/ - 4 vertices
/ - 4 faces
/ - 6 edges
/ This shape provides somewhat skewed results for a
/ sphere, especially at lower subdivisions.
/ I recommend that subdivisions of higher than 10
/ be used for acceptable results.

defs.name: TetraSphere
defs.docs: Tetrasphere (Sphere from tetrahedron).

attributes.value: / Tetrasphere (Sphere from tetrahedron).
/ See [`TetraSphereBase`].

defs.name: TriangleBase
defs.docs: Implements a single triangle as the base shape.

attributes.value: / Implements a single triangle as the base shape.
/ - 3 vertices
/ - 1 face
/ - 3 edges
/ This is a triangle on the XZ plane. The circumscribed
/ circle on the triangle has radius 1.0.

defs.name: TrianglePlane
defs.docs: A triangle.

attributes.value: / A triangle.
/ See [`TriangleBase`].

defs.name: SquareBase
defs.docs: Implements a square as the base shape.

attributes.value: / Implements a square as the base shape.
/ - 4 vertices
/ - 2 faces
/ - 5 edges
/ This is a square on the XZ plane.

defs.name: SquarePlane
defs.docs: A square.

attributes.value: / A square.
/ See [`SquareBase`].

defs.name: CubeBase
defs.docs: Implements a cube as the base shape.

attributes.value: / Implements a cube as the base shape.
/ - 8 vertices
/ - 12 faces (2 triangles per face makes 12 technically)
/ - 18 edges
/ This is a cube where half the diagonal is 1.0. This is to
/ enable this to be used in making a sphere.

defs.name: CubeSphere
defs.docs: A cube sphere.

attributes.value: / A cube sphere.
/ See [`CubeBase`].

defs.name: BaseShape
defs.docs:
Defines the setup for a base shape, and the functions
 used in interpolation.

attributes.value: / Defines the setup for a base shape, and the functions
/ used in interpolation.
/ If you want to use a different interpolation function,
/ implement this trait for a new type, and carry over only
/ the properties you'd like to keep:
/ ```rust
/ # use hexasphere::BaseShape;
/ use hexasphere::{Triangle, shapes::IcoSphereBase};
/ use glam::Vec3A;
/ // Uses linear interpolation instead of spherical.
/ struct FlatIcosahedron;
/ impl BaseShape for FlatIcosahedron {
/     // Keep the initial parameters.
/     fn initial_points(&self) -> Vec<Vec3A> {
/         IcoSphereBase.initial_points()
/     fn triangles(&self) -> Box<[Triangle]> {
/         IcoSphereBase.triangles()
/     const EDGES: usize = IcoSphereBase::EDGES;
/     // Swap out what you'd like to change.
/     fn interpolate(&self, a: Vec3A, b: Vec3A, p: f32) -> Vec3A {
/         hexasphere::interpolation::lerp(a, b, p)
/     fn interpolate_half(&self, a: Vec3A, b: Vec3A) -> Vec3A {
/         hexasphere::interpolation::lerp_half(a, b)
/     fn interpolate_multiple(&self, a: Vec3A, b: Vec3A, indices: &[u32], points: &mut [Vec3A]) {
/         hexasphere::interpolation::lerp_multiple(a, b, indices, points);
/ Or, create your own shape, by changing the values for
/ [`initial_points`], [`triangles`], and [`EDGES`]. Check
/ the documentation for these members individually on how
/ they should be implemented.
/ [`initial_points`]: #tymethod.initial_points
/ [`triangles`]: #tymethod.triangles
/ [`EDGES`]: #associatedconstant.EDGES

defs.name: initial_points
defs.docs:
The initial vertices for the triangle. Note that
 `Vec3A::new` is not a `const fn()`, hence I recommend
 you use `lazy_static`. Check the source file for this
 crate and look for the constants module at the bottom
 for an example.

attributes.value: / The initial vertices for the triangle. Note that
/ `Vec3A::new` is not a `const fn()`, hence I recommend
/ you use `lazy_static`. Check the source file for this
/ crate and look for the constants module at the bottom
/ for an example.
/ Constraints on the points depend on the interpolation
/ function used:
/ - `slerp` requires normalized (magnitude 1) data.
/ - `lerp` doesn't care.
/ - `normalized_lerp` requires normalized (magnitude 1)
/ data.

defs.name: triangles
defs.docs: Base triangles for the shape.

attributes.value: / Base triangles for the shape.
/ - The fields `a`, `b`, and `c` define the indices for
/ the points of the triangles given the data present
/ in `initial_points`. Note that this crate assumes
/ points are in a counter clockwise ordering.
/ - The fields `ab_edge`, `bc_edge`, `ca_edge` mark the
/ index of the edge which `a`/`b`, `b`/`c`, and `c`/`a`
/ border respectively. While theoretically you could give
/ each triangle its own edge, minimizing edges saves on
/ memory footprint and performance.
/ - Triangles should be created through [`Triangle::new`].

defs.name: EDGES
defs.docs:
Number of unique edges defined in the contents of
 `triangles()`. This number is 5 for a square for
 example:
 ```text
 a - 0 - b
 |     / |
 3   4   1
 | /     |
 d - 2 - c
 ```

attributes.value: / Number of unique edges defined in the contents of
/ `triangles()`. This number is 5 for a square for
/ example:
/ ```text

defs.name: interpolate
defs.value: pub fn interpolate(&Self, Vec3A, Vec3A, f32) -> Vec3A
defs.docs:
Basic function used for interpolation. When `p` is
 `0.0`, `a` is expected. When `p` is `1.0`, `b` is
 expected. There are three options already implemented
 in this crate:
 - [`lerp`] implements linear interpolation.
 - [`geometric_slerp`] implements spherical
 interpolation. (Interpolates along an arc on a sphere)
 - [`normalized_lerp`] implements cheaper
 yet less accurate spherical interpolation. The accuracy
 decreases as the angle between the two points on the unit
 sphere increases.

attributes.value: / Basic function used for interpolation. When `p` is
/ `0.0`, `a` is expected. When `p` is `1.0`, `b` is
/ expected. There are three options already implemented
/ in this crate:
/ - [`lerp`] implements linear interpolation.
/ - [`geometric_slerp`] implements spherical
/ interpolation. (Interpolates along an arc on a sphere)
/ - [`normalized_lerp`] implements cheaper
/ yet less accurate spherical interpolation. The accuracy
/ decreases as the angle between the two points on the unit
/ sphere increases.
/ [`lerp`]: ../fn.lerp.html
/ [`geometric_slerp`]: ../fn.geometric_slerp.html
/ [`normalized_lerp`]: ../fn.normalized_lerp.html

defs.name: interpolate_half
defs.value: pub fn interpolate_half(&Self, Vec3A, Vec3A) -> Vec3A
defs.docs:
If an optimization is available for the case where `p`
 is `0.5`, this function should implement it. This defaults
 to calling `interpolate(a, b, 0.5)` however.

attributes.value: / If an optimization is available for the case where `p`
/ is `0.5`, this function should implement it. This defaults
/ to calling `interpolate(a, b, 0.5)` however.

defs.name: interpolate_multiple
defs.docs:
If an optimization is available for the case where `p`
 varies but `a` and `b` don't this function should implement
 it.

attributes.value: / If an optimization is available for the case where `p`
/ varies but `a` and `b` don't this function should implement
/ it.
/ ### Parameters
/ - `a`: start.
/ - `b`: end.
/ - `indices`: list of indices to index into `points`. `points`
/ at the index should contain the result. The index (n) of an
/ index should correspond with the nth point in a distribution
/ of `indices.len()` points between (exclusive) `a` and `b`.
/ - `points`: list of points where the results of the calculation
/ should end up. To be indexed by values in `indices`.

defs.name: EquilateralBaseShape
defs.docs:
Implemented in the case where the triangles on the shape
 are both equilateral and identifiable from their normal.

attributes.value: / Implemented in the case where the triangles on the shape
/ are both equilateral and identifiable from their normal.
/ This is only used in the cases of spherical shapes.

defs.name: triangle_normals
defs.docs:
Normals for each of the triangles provided by
 [`BaseShape::triangles`].

attributes.value: / Normals for each of the triangles provided by
/ [`BaseShape::triangles`].

defs.name: triangle_min_dot
defs.docs:
Minimum value for the dot product which one could use
 to determine that triangle being the closest.

attributes.value: / Minimum value for the dot product which one could use
/ to determine that triangle being the closest.
/ If the dot product between a vector and a triangle
/ normal is greater than this, then that vector is
/ guaranteed to be within that triangle.
/ This is also the cosine of the angle of the cone
/ whose circular edge lies on a triangle.

defs.name: Triangle
defs.value: Triangle { a, b, c, ab_edge, bc_edge, ca_edge }
defs.docs: A main triangle on the base shape of a subdivided shape.

attributes.value: / A main triangle on the base shape of a subdivided shape.
/ The specification of the library expects `a`, `b`, and `c`
/ to be in a counter-clockwise winding.

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub const fn new(u32, u32, u32, usize, usize, usize) -> Self
defs.docs:
Creates a new `Triangle` given the data. This is done
 to avoid boilerplate.

attributes.value: / Creates a new `Triangle` given the data. This is done
/ to avoid boilerplate.

defs.name: Subdivided
defs.docs:
A progressively subdivided shape which can record
 the indices of the points and list out the individual
 triangles of the resulting shape.

attributes.value: / A progressively subdivided shape which can record
/ the indices of the points and list out the individual
/ triangles of the resulting shape.
/ All base triangles specified by `S` in [`BaseShape`]
/ are expected to be in counter clockwise winding.
/ Points are preferably stored with coordinates less
/ than or equal to `1.0`. This is why all default shapes
/ lie on the unit sphere.

defs.name: new
defs.value:
pub fn new<impl FnMut(Vec3A) -> T: FnMut(Vec3A) ->
           T>(usize, impl FnMut(Vec3A) -> T) -> Self

defs.name: new_custom_shape
defs.value:
pub fn new_custom_shape<impl FnMut(Vec3A) -> T: FnMut(Vec3A) ->
                        T>(usize, impl FnMut(Vec3A) -> T, S) -> Self
defs.docs: Creates the base shape from `S` and subdivides it.

attributes.value: / Creates the base shape from `S` and subdivides it.
/ - `subdivisions` specifies the number of times a subdivision
/ will be created. In other terms, this is the number of auxiliary
/ points between the vertices on the original shape.
/ - `generator` is a function run once all the subdivisions are
/ applied and its values are stored in an internal `Vec`.

defs.name: raw_points
defs.docs: The raw points created by the subdivision process.

attributes.value: / The raw points created by the subdivision process.

defs.name: get_indices
defs.docs: Appends the indices for the triangle into `buffer`.

attributes.value: / Appends the indices for the triangle into `buffer`.
/ The specified triangle is a main triangle on the base
/ shape. The range of this should be limited to the number
/ of triangles in the base shape.
/ Alternatively, use [`get_all_indices`] to get all the
/ indices.
/ [`get_all_indices`]: #method.get_all_indices

defs.name: get_all_indices
defs.docs: Gets the indices for all main triangles in the shape.

attributes.value: / Gets the indices for all main triangles in the shape.

defs.name: subdivisions
defs.docs:
Returns the number of subdivisions applied when this shape
 was created.

attributes.value: / Returns the number of subdivisions applied when this shape
/ was created.

defs.name: raw_data
defs.docs: Returns the custom data created by the generator function.

attributes.value: / Returns the custom data created by the generator function.

defs.name: indices_per_main_triangle
defs.docs:
Calculate the number of indices which each main
 triangle will add to the vertex buffer.

attributes.value: / Calculate the number of indices which each main
/ triangle will add to the vertex buffer.
/ # Equation
/ ```text
/ (subdivisions + 1)²

defs.name: vertices_per_main_triangle_shared
defs.docs:
Calculate the number of vertices contained within
 each main triangle including the vertices which are
 shared with another main triangle.

attributes.value: / Calculate the number of vertices contained within
/ each main triangle including the vertices which are
/ shared with another main triangle.
/ # Equation
/ ```text
/ (subdivisions + 1) * (subdivisions + 2) / 2

defs.name: vertices_per_main_triangle_unique
defs.docs:
Calculate the number of vertices contained within each
 main triangle excluding the ones that are shared with
 other main triangles.

attributes.value: / Calculate the number of vertices contained within each
/ main triangle excluding the ones that are shared with
/ other main triangles.
/ # Equation
/ ```text
/ { subdivisions < 2  : 0
/ { subdivisions >= 2 : (subdivisions - 1) * subdivisions / 2

defs.name: shared_vertices
defs.docs:
Calculate the number of vertices along the edges
 of the main triangles and the vertices of the main
 triangles.

attributes.value: / Calculate the number of vertices along the edges
/ of the main triangles and the vertices of the main
/ triangles.
/ # Equation
/ ```text
/ subdivisions * EDGES + INITIAL_POINTS
